PROJECT oBJECTIVES The overall objective of the project is to prevent further deterioration in the health status of the population, while at the same time improving the efficiency of the health care delivery system. More specifically the objectives of the project are to: (i) facilitate restructuring of the health sector by strengthening the policy analysis and management capacity in the sector; and (ii) protect the population at large--and vulnerable groups in particular--by ensuring continuing provision of essential health services during the transition period and beyond. DESCRIIION: The Project will be implemented over a five-year period by the MOH and concerned Municipalities. Total project cost is estimated at US$47.0 million (including contingencies). The Project will finance specialist advisory assistance, overseas and local training, study visits, materials, equipment, computer hardware and software, facilities rehabilitation, and incremental recurrent costs. The Project comprises four main components: (i) Policy Analysis and Management. This component would assist the MOH in building up a capacity for policy analysis and evaluation and would finance a limited number of key studies such as a burden of disease analysis and cost-effectiveness studies. The component would also finance computer software and hardware, as well as basic office equipment to support the Economic Analysis Unit and the network of Regional Health Centers, as they introduce new methodologies related to public health sector restructuring and flexible budgeting, and monitor and evaluate the implementation of health sector reforms. The component will also finance long-term and short-term fellowships in the areas of health planning, management, economics and finance, and
 - iv - health education and communications, as well as public information activities. (ii) Primary Health Care. This component will improve the quality and scope of primary health care in selected municipalities, which are committed to the introduction of the reform of health services delivery and financing, and to improve the efficiency of the health sector. The component will finance minor rehabilitation, equipment and furniture for up to 270 local health centers and 42 polyclinics. It will also finance consultant services to assist MOH and Municipal Councils to plan PHC activities, design and implement the new package of PHC services and training programs for medical doctors, nurses and other health and social workers and well targeted municipal health promotion activities. (iii) Emergency Medical Services. This component will support ongoing efforts by MOH to restructure emergency medical services and improve the effectiveness and efficiency of service delivery, by separating EMS functions from those of the PHC network and creating a three-tiered national EMS network. The component will finance minor civil works for base stations at the periphery and minor civil works and equipment for two types of emergency rooms (21 regional hospital and 45 community hospital emergency rooms). In addition, it will finance 29 properly equipped intervention vehicles for the medical teams, and 96 ambulances for the basic life support teams in the pre-hospital services. The component will also finance consultant services to assist in completing the conception, in coordinating the implementation, and in managing the EMS and in training medical, paramedical and administrative staff. (iv) Blood Transfusion. This component will assist current efforts to improve the supply and quality of blood and blood products by restructuring and rehabilitating the network of blood transfusion centers, by introducing safer and more up to date technology and by promoting actively the recruitment of new donors. The component will finance minor civil works and equipment to renovate existing facilities of the National Center for Clinical and Transfusion Hematology (NCCTH) and the five Regional Transfusion Hematology Centers (RTHCs) in Sofia, Plovdiv, Pleven, Stara Zagora, and Varna. It will also finance technical assistance to design programs, and training for health personnel engaged in donor recruitment, public relations, blood collection and processing, and quality control.
 - v BENEFITS: The project will have four major benefits. It will: (i) contribute to economic growth and increased lifetime income for individuals through the impact of improved health status on labor productivity, fewer work loss days, a longer working life, increased ability of individuals to obtain better jobs, and (through the positive interaction of health and education) increased enrollment and improved ability to learn; (ii) reduce poverty and improve equity by targeting health interventions to the poor who stand to gain the most in economic terms from improvements in health status; (iii) increase the efficiency of the health system by focusing on health interventions (e.g. preventive and primary) that are known to be the most cost effective, i.e., those that yield the greatest gains in disability adjusted life years per unit cost (through a decrease in infant, maternal and other adult mortality, lower levels of disability associated with various degrees of illness), and by improving the institutional organization, service delivery, and input utilization of the health sector; and, (iv) improve fiscal balance and promote macro-economic stability by containing cost escalation in the health sector. RISKS: The most important risk faced by the project lies in the lack of experience and weak managerial capabilities of MOH staff engaged in a major reform and restructuring program. This risk will be offset by building on and expanding ongoing programs which are being implemented successfully by other donors and by financing a supporting technical assistance and training program. Other risks are linked to the country's exceptional conditions. For instance, political uncertainties still inhibit the full commitment of some officials to the reform program. Moreover, unrealistic expectations are often generated by a misconception of Western systems or optimistic views on the time and resources required to develop and introduce a specific reform. These risks will be somewhat mitigated by financing information activities aimed at building a national consensus on health sector reform and initiatives to break the isolation of MOH staff and develop professional contacts with other Western institutions.

 BULGARIA HEALTH SECTOR RESTRUCTURING PROJECT STAFF APPRAISAL REPORT I. BACKGROUND AND RATIONALE A. Introduction 1.1 Bulgaria began the transition to a market economy with a well developed health infrastructure and good health indicators in many respects. However, as economic conditions deteriorated, health indicators stopped progressing and even declined in some instances. Indicators show a rising infant mortality, rising incidence of tuberculosis, epidemics of communicable diseases, decreased availability of blood products, increasing incidence of iodine deficiency, and imminent collapse of blood transfusion and hematology. As transition to a market-oriented economic and restructuring of the health system are medium-term processes, there is a real danger of further deterioration of current trends before a new health system performs adequately. 1.2 In keeping with the transition to a more market-oriented economy, the country is moving from a highly centralized, public sector health system toward a more diverse and decentralized system in which the private sector is expected to play a crucial--yet still indeterminate--role. However, the fast pace of decentralization of the health care delivery system and the unregulated emergence of private health care providers pose a real threat to the quality of health care. The Ministry of Health (MOH) and the medical community are wrestling with the most complex and often controversial issues such as the introduction of health insurance, the allocation of resources in a decentralized setting and the means to encourage greater efficiency and improved quality of health services. 1.3 The system places a heavy fiscal burden on a country where per capita income has fallen from US$2,680 in 1989 to only US$1,160 in 1993. Govemment revenues have contracted by 50 percent in real terms since 1989. Despite the loss of revenues, expenditure in the health sector was maintained in real terms until 1993, when across the board budget cuts were introduced. Nonetheless, the situation remains financially unsustainable, and the system needs to adjust to the new fiscal reality. The urgency of reform has been heightened by the political, economic and social forces which have come into play during the transition. This first project in the health sector in Bulgaria will promote the necessary adjustments in the health care system, while at the same time providing urgent investments aimed at protecting key health services which are part of the safety net and essential for developing the country's human capital.
 - 2 - B. Health Status of the Population'' 1.4 Since the 1950s, the health of the population has substantially improved as shown by the trends in most health indicators. This improvement, however, has lagged since 1985 and appears to be reversing itself in the last four or five years. Like many East European countries, Bulgaria faces a major challenge in improving the health of its adult population, particularly low income groups and minorities. 1.5 Bulgaria's population of about 9 million is aging rapidly, and is expected to remain stable till the end of the century.Y' The crude birth rate (10.0 per thousand) has fallen below the replacement level and, since 1990, there have been more deaths than births. Total fertility declined from 2.1 to 1.9 live births per woman during the 1965-1990 period. The crude death rate (12 per thousand) is on the rise, largely due to the aging of the population. The aging process will reduce the 0-14 years age group from 19.9 percent of the total population in 1990 to 17.9 percent in 2025; at the same time, the 65 years and above group will increase from 13.5 to more than 21 percent. 1.6 Bulgaria is one of the few developed countries where life expectancy--one of the most fundamental indicators of health status--has not increased significantly since 1970. Life expectancy at birth for males has actually decreased (68.1 in 1962 and 68.0 in 1992) while it increased for women (from 71.7 to 75.0 during the same time period). High rates of internal migration have resulted in a 67 percent urbanization rate (46 percent in 1965) and a high concentration in rural areas of elderly people who require more services. The health status worsened in rural areas, due to lower quality of health services and deteriorating socio- economic conditions which especially affect the elderly population. Ethnic minority groups also have a poorer health status and less access to basic health care. 1.7 A review of health indicators shows that infant mortality is high (22nd out of 27 countries in Europe) and rising from 13.6 per 1,000 in 1988 to 15.9 in 1992. Similarly maternal mortality is high (24th out of 27). Among women, besides the high maternal mortality, a high standardized death rate (SDR) for cancer of the cervix, a highly preventable disease, is noteworthy (21st out of 27). Due to the unavailability of modern contraceptives, Bulgaria has one of the highest abortion rates in the world and, since the early 1970s, abortions have outnumbered births (1.4 abortions per live birth in 1991). Immunization rates, which were among the highest in Europe, have recently decreased. Among children, the most frequent causes of death in 1992 were conditions of the perinatal period (29%), congenital malformations (26%) and diseases of the respiratory system (24%). 1' For a more comprehensive analysis see Annex 2: The Health of the Bulgarian Population. High mortality is explained by a very high SDR (0-64) for circulatory system diseases (25th out of 27), with the highest SDR for cerebrovascular diseases in Europe. Diseases of the circulatory system are major contributors to the increasing difference in mortality rates between Bulgaria and Western EuropeY In terms of morbidity, the most frequent reasons for seeking health services in 1992 were: diseases of the digestive system (44%); diseases of the nervous system (12%); diseases of the locomotion system (7%); diseases of the respiratory system (7%); accidents, poisonings and violence (7%). More importantly, however, the main causes of hospitalization4' confirm again the high prevalence and seriousness of cardiovascular and respiratory diseases in Bulgaria. 1.9 Finally, lifestyle is a major factor affecting mortality and morbidity patterns. Tobacco consumption is on the rise in the population below 35 (especially in the 11-15 age group) and among women and alcohol consumption is relatively high. The percentage of fat in the diet, although below European average, is increasing. Finally, mortality from traffic accidents and suicide correspond to European averages, but male mortality from injury and poisoning is much higher. As in other Eastern European countries environment related health problems seem to be concentrated in the most industrialized areas. C. Health Care Organization and Financing-' 1.10 The Bulgarian health system is characteristic of most former socialist economies, with: (i) tax-based financing; (ii) public sector provision of services; (iii) universal access to comprehensive care; (iv) centralized planning and management; (v) extensive infrastructure and staffing; and (vi) few incentives for consumers or providers to increase efficiency, control costs and improve the quality of care. The public sector health system is organized along the lines of district and municipal administration, and consists of: (i) rural health posts, district health centers and urban polyclinics (freestanding and hospital-based) for ambulatory care; (ii) municipal hospitals (250-300 beds each) and district hospitals (1,000 beds each) for secondary care; and (iii) medical academies and a wide variety of specialized hospitals and institutes for tertiary care. Private sector health services were authorized in 1991 and have grown rapidly in the liberalized and largely unregulated pharmaceutical sector, prompting the exodus of 40 percent of pharmacists from the public sector. At the same time, the development of private medical services has been slowed by, among other factors, the lack of an appropriate financing mechanism. 1.12 The most fundamental reform of the Bulgarian health system to date has been the decentralization of management and financing of health facilities to the municipalities in which they are located, including district hospitals and district-based, specialized institutes, which have catchment areas extending beyond a single municipality. All local health facilities have the legal status of municipal enterprises, limiting their managerial and financial autonomy. National-level institutes and hospitals have the status of autonomous public enterprises--with some falling under the supervision of the MOH. District and municipal health services are financed almost exclusively from a municipal budget which is distinct from the central, or republican budget. However, the municipal budget is dominated by transfers from central budgetary revenues. A key issue following the decentralization of health system management has been the need to match resources at the municipal level with health care responsibilities, particularly when catchment areas extend beyond a single municipality. 1.13 Despite the unprecedented economic and fiscal contraction, the Government succeeded in maintaining--and even moderately increasing--aggregate real spending for health during this period until 1992. This is in marked contrast to most other former socialist economies, where economic contraction has resulted, to varying degrees, in compression of real health expenditures. As a result, public spending for health rose as a share of GDP from 3.4 percent in 1989 to a peak of 5.4 percent in 1992--a level which is not high by Western European standards, but is in the upper range for countries at Bulgaria's income level. Given the magnitude of the fiscal contraction, health expenditures nearly doubled as a share of government spending, from 5.8 percent in 1989 to 11.9 percent in 1992. However, fiscal pressures made spending cuts inevitable and health expenditures were trimmed to 5.1 percent of GDP in 1993, and 4.7 of GDP in 1994.

Major Issues for Health Sector Reform Breakdown of Essential Health Services 1.14 Bulgaria is undergoing a difficult transition characterized by severe economic dislocations, change from a centrally planned health system to a decentralized one, and an attempt to move from a publicly financed and provided health services delivery system to a publicly financed but both privately and publicly provided system. In line with the decline in health indicators over the last few years, there is increasing evidence that essential services have either deteriorated in quality or become too costly to sustain. (i) Primary Health Care 1.15 In Bulgaria, the first point of contact in the public health system--Primary Health Care (PHC)--is neither comprehensive, nor clearly differentiated from costly emergency medical services. Provision of family medicine through general practitioners and/or paramedical practitioners is a new concept. Physicians at the primary level tend to be both overspecialized and unfamiliar with some elements of the basic package of PHC services, particularly in the areas of disease prevention and health promotion. 1.16 Maternal and perinatal mortality are very high in Bulgaria due to a number of factors such as: the low quality of perinatal care, the lack of appropriate follow up in the case of high risk pregnancy, the difficulties in the emergency referral system, the poor availability of modem contraceptive services, and the limited availability of blood products. Improved management of obstetrical and neonatal care in PHC, with stronger linkage to emergency services needs to be developed. 1.17 With the decentralization of health services, it has become increasingly difficult for cash-strapped municipalities to ensure even a minimum level of service. Rapid price increases have led to shortages of consumables and restrictions on utilities. Basic maintenance of facilities and equipment is often not ensured. Lack of financial incentives and essential supplies has demotivated medical staff, who have migrated toward the hospital sector, leaving 1,400 positions vacant at the primary level. As a result, patients tend to bypass the primary system, seeking less cost-effective treatment in hospitals. 1.18 The economic transition has intensified the need for comprehensive reform of the health system. At the primary level, measures have been undertaken to train general practitioners, as well as establish the legal and regulatory framework, and define new
 - 6 - reimbursement mechanisms, for private sector providers. Private outpatient services, particularly for family medicine, are slowly emerging.6' 1.19 However, the public sector will continue to have an important role to play-- particularly in poorer, more isolated municipalities--in maintaining a minimum PHC network. Maintaining this network, as part of the public sector social safety net, is crucial during the economic transition, but also beyond, as evidence shows in well-established market economies in Western Europe and elsewhere. If the public sector in Bulgaria is to fulfill its responsibility to provide this key component of the social safety net, reforms in the structure, scope and organization of primary health services are called for. Investments tightly linked to measures aimed at improving the utilization of existing facilities and improving the efficiency of services are also necessary. (ii) Emergency Medical Services 1.20 Emergency medical services (EMS) play a pivotal role, allowing the population direct access to critical care for life-threatening and other emergency situations. They also link the PHC sector to more specialized levels of services, through organized communication and transport. Beyond the usual response to, management and transport of real emergencies, EMS in Bulgaria provide house calls and transport for routine non- emergency care. These services could be handled more effectively and more efficiently by a public or private PHC. 1.21 In a country where cardiovascular diseases and accidents are leading causes of mortality, EMS are provided by a fragmented network of pre-hospital and hospital institutions with no clear definition of responsibilities and linkages. No national standards for the organization, financing, or quality of care of EMS are enforced. The low quality and the inefficiency of the services provided has become even more obvious with the decentralization of health care delivery and with the limitations of municipal budgets. 1.22 There is no separation between primary care and emergency services, and emergency medical teams, both in mobile units and in health centers and small hospitals, de facto cater in most cases (up to 85%) to a family practice type of demand, and handle few critical emergencies. This vertical separation of clinical services leads to expensive duplication. The concept of a unified, polyvalent emergency room does not exist, and transfers to specialized services are not controlled. 1.23 The system is generously staffed, although the training of medical and non- medical personnel is inappropriate. In large cities, pre-hospital medical teams are overspecialized, as are most medical teams on call in hospitals. (iii) Blood Transfusion 1.25 The sector of transfusion is a vital element of any public heath care delivery system. However, the present status of blood transfusion in Bulgaria does not meet basic criteria such as an adequate supply of high quality blood and blood components, or ensure adequate safety for blood donors and recipients. 1.26 The current technology for blood collection and processing is out-of-date and presents a great hazard for transmission of infectious agents to both patients and health personnel. The utilization of glass bottles as containers limits the volume of donated blood. A simple switch to collection in plastic bags will increase the amount of blood collected from the same number of donors by 12,000 liters and extend the shelf life by 24 days (i.e., will decrease the amount of out-dated blood and increase the availability of blood components for transfusion). 1.27 Improper processing and storage reduces the yield and activity of plasma components such as antihemophilic globulin. Moreover, the utilization of glass bottles for blood collection does not permit preparation of purified blood components such as leukocyte-free red blood cells and platelets. This in turn eliminates the possibility of proper treatment for patients undergoing chemotherapy for bone marrow or solid cancer. Z' The fleet includes some 2,800 ambulances and cars. Virtually no investments have been made since the 1970s and a large number of vehicles should be written off. 1/ The volume of blood collected in a glass bottle is 340 ml, as compared to 400 ml with plastic bag. Identification of donors and tests are handwritten, increasing the risks of errors. Tests for hepatitis, which are too costly, are not performed. Because of the lack of appropriate training, transfusion hematology does not comply with international standards. For example, the main product which is transfused is whole blood. This contradicts international standards and leads to loss of plasma which otherwise could be used for fractionation and production of plasma components. 1.29 The network of transfusion centers is highly inefficient and needs to be restructured. The current system comprises the National Center of Clinical and Transfusion Hematology (NCCTH), 4 Regional Transfusion Hematology Centers (RTHCs) and 28 District Transfusion Centers. These centers are currently under the administrative and financial control of municipalities, which makes it difficult to implement national policies and enforce standards. Each district center is engaged in blood collection and rudimentary blood processing, while blood banks exist in the major hospitals and in some regional hospitals. A restructuring of this network and downsizing of institutions could lead to significant efficiency gains. 1.30 Finally, the political, economic and social changes during the recent years have had an extremely negative impact on blood donation. Incentives provided to donors through the work place have all but disappeared, and as in other countries, there is a reluctance on the part of the population to donate blood. The total number of donors decreased from 44,000 in 1988 to 24,000 in 1992. Limited Emphasis on Health Promotion 1.31 Health promotion, including disease prevention, is recognized as one of the most cost-effective approaches for reducing the incidence of many acute and chronic diseases. Because health promotion has been largely ignored as an element in Bulgaria's public health strategy, the population has access to insufficient and/or outdated information on the relationships between lifestyle and health. 1.32 SDRs for cerebrovascular and cardiovascular diseases in Bulgaria are among the nighest in the world and rising, along with those for diabetes, cirrhosis, and cancers of the lung, breast and digestive organs. The role which lifestyle factors play in increasing the morbidity and premature mortality from these chronic diseases is well-established. These factors are most prevalent in industrialized countries, and Bulgaria is no exception with a relatively high-fat, high-sodium diet, a sedentary lifestyle, and widespread abuse of cigarettes and alcohol. Cigarette smoking continues to rise--especially among young adults--increasing manyfold the relative risk of not only lung cancer, but also cardiovascular disease.

With 3.1 physicians and 12.3 hospital beds per 1,000 inhabitants, and a primary care center for every 2,400 inhabitants, Bulgaria has medical staffing and service capacity which are at the high end of the range for both Central and Eastern European (CEE) countries and countries with established market economies. The existence of parallel delivery systems, maintained by other Ministries such as the Ministry of Defense or the Ministry of Transports makes it also difficult for MOH to control investments in the sector. This system places a heavy fiscal burden on a country where per capita income and government revenues have contracted significantly over a very short period of time. 1.34 Tax-based health systems such as Bulgaria's offer the advantages of facilitating universal access to care and minimizing financial risk for health care consumers. However, budget allocations to facilities are based largely on historical levels of fixed and quasi-fixed inputs: number of facilities, beds and staff. Allocations do not reflect anticipated service volume, nor have they been adjusted to take into account shifting patterns of service utilization in recent years. As a result, the existing budgetary system suffers from: (i) few incentives for cost consciousness among consumers, who pay no out-of-pocket costs for care; (ii) no transfer of financial risk (or reward) to providers in order to create incentives to improve efficiency, consolidate redundant services and improve quality to attract clientele; and (iii) no reimbursement mechanism for private services which will foster private sector development. 1.35 It is clear that inefficient allocation of resources is limiting the effectiveness of the system in preventing and reversing recent declines in health status. Increased efficiency in resource use is necessary to enhance both the effectiveness of the system in protecting the health of the population, and its fiscal sustainability. In the absence of more fundamental financial reform, the Ministries of Health and Finance have sought to improve the existing system of municipal budgeting by developing "objective criteria" to determine municipal transfers. However, the methodology is applied to only a small share (11 percent in 1994) of aggregate municipal transfers, resulting in little reallocation of resources relative to the past. Facility and personnel norms have also been established to guide restructuring, but are not based on an analysis of service utilization either in Bulgaria or in other countries. 1.36 In the longer run, adoption of contributory national health insurance legislation has tended to be viewed as a panacea for health financing and management problems. However, the draft legislation which was submitted to Parliament fails to take into account the extremely limited scope for additional payroll taxation as a source of new revenues. It also does not define specific reimbursement mechanisms. C. Project Economic Justification 2.30 The project will have three major benefits. It will: (i) improve health status; (ii) improve equity and reduce poverty; (iii) increase efficiency in the health sector; and (iv) improve fiscal balance and promote macro-economic stability by containing cost escalation in the health sector. 2.31 Improve Health Status. Improvements in health status will contribute to economic growth and increased life time income for individuals through the impact of improved health status on labor productivity, fewer work loss days, a longer working life, increased ability of individuals to obtain better jobs, and (through the positive interaction of health and education) increased enrollment and improved ability to learn. 2.32 Current health outcomes in Bulgaria are amongst the lowest in Europe. In marked contrast to international trends, life expectancy has actually declined over the past 25 years as a result of premature death from chronic diseases associated with unhealthy life styles. Life expectancy for males, in particular, has declined between 1960 and 1992. Adult mortality rates from cardio-vascular disease are the second highest in Europe while mortality rates from cerebro-vascular disease are the highest in the region. Infant mortality rates are the sixth highest in Europe and the long-term downward trend has worsened during the transition. This is due, in part, to the re-emergence of infectious diseases. The country has recently gone through major measles (1992) and tuberculosis (1990) epidemics. Maternal mortality rates are third highest in the region, while mortality from cervical cancer have been increasing and are the seventh highest in Europe. 2.33 The project will improve health status by the most cost effective method: strengthening preventive and curative care at the primary level to address the leading causes of high mortality rates in infants, children and adults.  - 85 - Annex 2 Page 2 of 19 BULGARIA HEALTH SECTOR RESTRUCTURING PROJECT THE HEALTH OF THE BULGARIAN POPULATION I. COUNTRY BACKGROUND 1. Since the 1950s, the health of the Bulgarian population has substantially improved as shown by trends in most of the broad health indicators (Table 1). This improvement, however, has lagged since 1985 and appears to be reversing itself in the last 4- 5 years. Progressive aging of the population contributes to this situation and raises problems of constantly increasing social and medical costs, a phenomenon common to all European countries. Specific death rates by age show a significant increase among persons aged 40 to 59 over the last 30 years. This increase is essentially due to the excess mortality among males in this age group. Hence, the health of the middle-aged adult is a challenge to the Bulgarian health system. 2. The Bulgarian Health System has major assets, in particular excellent access to health care provided "free of charge" to the population through an extensive network of health centers, polyclinics, hospitals and institutes. The system, however, is rather inefficient, as discussed in Annex 3, because of its duplication, overstaffing, inadequate management and poorly allocated recurrent budget. Consequently, the system places a heavy fiscal burden on a country where government revenues have contracted by 50 percent in real terms since 1989. Despite this contraction, the Government maintained health expenditure in real terms until 1993. However, the inevitable adjustment of public health expenditure to the fiscal crisis, combined with the fast pace of decentralization of the health care delivery system and the unregulated emergence of private health care providers is leading to further deterioration in the quality of health care. 3. Over the past three years the Government has taken a number of painful but necessary steps to improve the balance between available resources and expenditures: limits on medical school enrolment, restructuring of the Medical Academy and of the medical schools, closure of excess sanatoria beds (around 3,400), privatization of the drug distribution system, and setting new norms for medical services. The Ministry of Health and the medical community are now wrestling with the most complex and often controversial issues such as the financing of health services, the allocation of resources in a decentalized setting and the types of incentives to improve both greater efficiency and quality of health services.

Stagnation or deterioration in health indicators appears to be due, inter alia, to the lack of investment in the sector because of a declining economic situation, and to the inefficient utilization of the recurrent budget. Consequently, this led to a deep deterioration of the health system, in particular the primary health care (PHC) system, which could not fulfill its "triage" role. The lack of effectiveness of PHC has put additional stress on an already overwhelmed emergency and hospital system. II. POPULATION 5. According to the 1992 census, the population of Bulgaria was 8.484.900, with sixty seven percent of the population living in urban areas. The distribution of the population by Region and by urban/rural residence is presented in Table 2 and the structure by age and sex is presented in Table 3. It is worth noting that the rural population is older, and the proportion of working age group (ages 15 to 59) is less than in urban areas. The broad trends in population dynamics indicate: (a) a progressive aging of the population over the past 35 years (from 13% over 60 years of age in 1965 to 20% in 1992); (b) a rapid urbanization of the population between 1946 and 1980 (urban population of 25% in 1946 and 62.5% in 1980), with a slow down in recent years (67% in 1992); (c) very little improvement of life expectancy at birth over the past 35 years (from 69.59 in 1960 to 71.21 in 1993) except for women (71.35 in 1960 to 74.66 in 1991); and (d) as in other European countries, a low rate of population growth since the 1970s and even a negative growth rate since 1990. This last trend is related to a decrease in natality (lower fertility rate and smaller number of women of reproductive age), coupled to an increase in mortality linked to the aging population. 6. Table 4 shows that Bulgaria's natality is at the low end amongst the countries of Eastem Europe and tends towards Western Europe's pattern. In recent years, the lack of population growth has been exacerbated by an important emigration of young adults. Although the Total Fertility Rate shows a decline from 2.31 in 1960 to 1.45 in 1993, there is little use of modem methods of family planning. 7. Reproductive health has the same characteristics as in most East European countries i.e. reliance on abortion as the main method of fertility control. While the contraceptive
 - 87 - Annex 2 Page 4 of 19 prevalence rate was estimated to be 76% in the late 1970s, it was mainly traditional methods. The number of abortions is reported to be around 130,000-150,000 per year over the last ten years. The ratio of abortions to live births was 1,480 abortions per 1,000 births in 1992. This corresponds approximately to an average of 2.3 abortions per woman during her reproductive period. This situation appears due in part to (i) the high cost of contraception in comparison to abortion; (ii) the lack of adequate contraceptive education at the time of abortion; (iii) the lack of involvement of the medical and paramedical professions in contraception, except for gynecologists; and (iv) cultural factors. mI. HEALTH STATUS 8. If the lack of improvement of the health situation of the adult population, in particular for males (reduced life expectancy of males, increased cardio- and cerebrovascular pathology), is a long standing problem, the deterioration of infant health appeared at the end of the 1980s. Life expectancy at birth for males has not improved since 1960 (from 67.8 years in 1960 to 67.6 years in 1992) and actually has decreased since 1965, when it reached 68.8 years (Table 5). By comparison life expectancy at birth for males is 75 in Sweden, 73 in France and 74 in The Netherlands. There is also a clear excess mortality among males between the ages of 15 and 49. The death rate (age 15 - 49) in 1991 was 2.17/1,000 males and of 0.97/1,000 females. This remains a major health problem for the health sector in Bulgaria. 9. Tables 6 and 7 indicate that in 1991 Bulgaria's health indicators were lagging behind many European countries. However, when compared to countries of similar per capita income (Table 7) Bulgaria has better health than the average Lower-Middle-Income Country. A. Health Indicators 10. Between 1960 and 1990 the trends in health indicators show that: (a) Life expectancy in Bulgaria is low compared to most European countries, in particular for men (67.6 in 1992), and has not improved since 1965. (b) Infant mortality has decreased from 45.1 per 1,000 live births in 1960, to 13.6 in 1988, it should be noted, however, that there has been a recent significant increase in infant mortality (from 13.6 per thousand in 1988 to 16.9 per thousand in 1991 with a decrease to 15.9 in 1992 and to 15.5 in 1993).

(c) In spite of a substantial decrease over the past 30 years, maternal mortality (20 per 100,000 live births in 1980-90) is among the highest in Europe (25th highest out of 27 European countries). (d) A rise in the mortality rate of the population in the 40 - 59 age group (from 3.4 per thousand in 1960 to 4.6 in 1993 for the 40-49 age group, and from 8.1 per thousand in 1960 to 10.6 per thousand in 1993 for the 50-59 age group). (e) Rural Bulgaria presents very different demographic and health indicators than the urban part of the country (see Table 8). Such differences may be due to: (i) the migration of the active population to the cities; (ii) lower economic and social development of rural areas; and (iii) lower access to quality health services. Expectedly, an older rural population experiences a higher crude death rate but there is also a real excess mortality in rural areas as evidenced by the age specific death rates by causes for infants and children (see Tables 9 and 10). B. Causes of Death 11. The main causes of death, in 1993, were Cardiovascular diseases (62.7%), Cancer (14.3%), Senility and other Ill-defined Conditions (5.1%), Accidents, Poisoning and Violence (5.1 %), and Respiratory System diseases (5.6%) (see Table 11). This is not unexpected in a country with an aging population. Among infants the main causes of mortality are: (i) conditions related to the perinatal period; (ii) congenital malformation; (iii) diseases of the respiratory system; (iv) Accidents, Poisoning and Violence; and (v) infectious diseases. Adult Mortality 12. The mortality due to cardiovascular diseases in Bulgaria is among the highest in Europe and in particular among males. The standardized mortality rate at age 0-64 for diseases of the circulatory system was 160 per 100,000 population in 1990, thus placing Bulgaria in the 25th position in the group of 27 European countries. Among circulatory system diseases, cerebrovascular diseases, in Bulgaria, have the highest mortality in Europe and ischemic heart diseases have the 20th highest mortality among the 27 European Countries. This problem is most serious because, in contrast with the general trends in
 - 89 - Annex 2 Page 6 of 19 Europe, it has worsened in Bulgaria on an average of 2% per year during the 1980s. Arterial hypertension is frequent, even in young adults. 13. The cancer Standardized Mortality Rate (SMR) for age 0-64 was 91/100,000 population in 1990, which is below the European average, but rising. Under age 65, the standardized cancer mortality is 30.7 per 100,000 for digestive organs, 21.4 for trachea/bronchus/lung, 15.6 for breast and 4.2 for cervix (see table 7). Mortality for digestive organs and the uterine cervix are higher than the European averages, and are rising. 14. The standardized mortality rate (SMR 0-64) for diseases of the respiratory system was reported to be 70 in 1992 (24th highest among 31 European countries). Respiratory infections are the second most frequent cause of hospitalization after delivery and pregnancy. This may result from air pollution in some industrial areas, tobacco consumption (4.1 kg per inhabitant as compared to 1.5 kg in Sweden, 2.3 kg in France and 3.0 kg in the Netherlands in 1990), difficult living conditions, and inadequate health care services. 15. Accidents and intoxications are a relatively important cause of morbidity and mortality, especially in children (first cause of mortality in the 1-14 year age group), and in the young adult male. In contrast with the regression noted in most other European countries, mortality due to these causes was stable in Bulgaria over the last 10 years. 16. Infectious and parasitic diseases are well controlled, with the exception of respiratory infections among children. One should stress, however, that a deterioration of the health system and/or of the socio-economic situation could easily reverse this process. A case in point is the increased incidence of tuberculosis since 1990 and the epidemic of measles in 1992. Maternal and Infant Mortality 17. Although enormous progress has been achieved in the last 30 years, indicators of maternal and child health are still poor when compared with Western European countries. Health status of children 18. Perinatal mortality has fallen from 18.8/1.000 live births in 1960 to 10.8 in 1989, to rise again to 13.2 in 1992. In 1990 this was 7 in Sweden; 9 in France, and 10 in the Netherlands. Infant mortality reached its lowest level in 1988 (13.6/1,000 live births) but increased to 15.5/1,000 in 1993 (against 6 in Sweden, 7 in France, and 8 in the Netherlands in the same year). Under-5 mortality rate is 21/1,000 (against 8 in Sweden, 9 in France and 9 in the Netherlands in 1990). 19. The main causes of infant mortality are, in decreasing order: (i) problems related to the perinatal period (for instance delivery) (29%); (ii) congenital malformations

In children aged 1 to 5 years, the main causes of death are respiratory diseases and congenital abnormalities. The first cause of mortality from age 1 to 14 are accidents and poisoning (36%). Maternal Health 20. Maternal mortality, with 20 maternal deaths for 100,000 live births in the 1980s, remains one of the highest in Europe. This could be due in part to inadequate labor and delivery services and to the persistence of non-medical abortions in spite of their legalization (apparently many women are unable to obtain the procedure during the 12 week limit). The causes for this situation are certainly multiple but the quality of perinatal care, the management of high risk pregnancy, the emergency referral system, abortion legislation and management, and the availability of blood products appear to play an important role. C. Morbidity 21. The number of cases of illness registered in 1992 in medical establishments was above 12 million of which 37% were children under 15 years or 2.7 contacts per child per year. There was on average 1.1 registered illness per year and per adult in 1992. In the same year, there was 1.4 million discharges from hospitals (17% were children under 15). Among communicable diseases, the five most frequent ones, in 1992, were influenza, chicken pox, measles, hepatitis and rubeola. In 1991, insured working personnel were absent from work an average 7.48 days per person. 22. The major reasons for consulting the general health services in 1993 were: (i) diseases of respiratory system (41.8%); (ii) diseases of the nervous system and of the sense organs (12,6%); (iii) diseases of the circulatory system (7.3%); (iv) diseases of the skin and cellular tissue (7%); and (v) genito-urinary system (5.4%). Again in 1993, the principal causes for hospitalization were: deliveries and complications of pregnancy (18.8%), diseases of the respiratory system (16.5%), diseases of the circulatory system (11.6%), and diseases of the genito-urinary system (9.4%). 23. While the high degree of environmental pollution in Eastern European countries is well known, (especially industrial pollution) it is not easy to demonstrate a clear linkage with the morbidity. One should, however, mention the elevated lead contents of blood in children and adults in Pernik, Plovdiv, Asenovgard, and Vratsa. A high incidence of lung cancer has also been reported in highly polluted areas, such as in Southern Bulgaria and in the area of Burgas (oil refinery). The role of environmental pollution in the high infant mortality due to respiratory diseases and congenital malformations is less clear.

The Ministry of health had been traditionally responsible for developing health policy, plans and budget, preparing health legislation, and evaluating the health status of the country, as well as delivering most services. Parallel health systems also exist for special groups of workers under the responsibility of the Armed Forces, the Ministry of Internal Affairs, the Ministry of Transportation and the Enterprise Medical Services. Most services are, however, publicly financed and publicly provided at no charge to the user. In 199?, the responsibility for the delivery of primary and secondary care was decentralized from the Ministry of Health to the Municipalities, which receive their budget directly from the Ministry of Finance (see Annex 3). The Ministry of Health manages several National Institutes and tertiary hospitals, paramedical schools, as well as a network of sanitary and epidemiological centers (ex SANEPID in the Soviet system). The epidemiology and sanitation centers have the responsibility , at the District level, for the quality of water, food, control of communicable diseases, pollution and other pestilence. The organigram of the Ministry of Health (MOH) is given in Chart 13. The National Center for Health Informatics, under the Ministry of Health, gathers health statistics for the whole country. 25. The private practice of medicine is presently authorized in Bulgaria but the lack of a Medical Insurance system and the past reliance on "free" medical services as well as the poor economic situation of the population have prevented the creation of a true private sector. The present situation is characterized by the "after hours" participation in the private sector of many publicly paid physicians but a total lack of incentives for them to forsake their public positions. 26. In 1993 the MOH gave high priority to addressing five main issues: (a) adopting a new mode of financing health services; (b) modifying the mode of practice of health care in particular the relationship between medical specialties and between public and private sectors; (c) improving access to quality family planning services; (d) preparing and implementing a new pharmaceutical policy; and (e) restructuring some critical medical sectors such as emergency care, transfusion services and oncology.
 -92 - Annex 2 Page 9 of 19 B. Level of Services and Physical Infrastructure 27. The front line of health services is made of Rural Health Centers and various types of Polyclinics, according to the rural or urban status of the areas and their population size. To a certain extent the ambulatory services of hospitals could also be included in this basic category. In 1993, 3,393 Rural Health Centers, 51 public Polyclinics, 10 enterprise Polyclinics and 93 dental clinics were operating. These basic structures refer their complicated patients to 95 Community Hospitals, 30 District Hospitals, 11 Enterprise Hospitals and to a large number of tertiary hospital structures (University, Institutes, pediatrics, mental, maternity, pulmonary, sanatoria, etc.). At the top of the pyramid the National Medical Institutes and the Medical Academy Hospital represent the ultimate reference centers. In 1993 there were 88,910 hospital beds and 19,278 sanatorium beds. 28. The health network provides a good coverage of the population. The quality of the health services is however hindered by the lack of investment (lack of equipment), poorly targeted recurrent budget (lack of consumables, low salaries of health professionals) and by the lack of incentives in the primary health care sector. But in terms of quantity of outpatient structures or hospital beds, Bulgaria with 1,056 beds per 100,000 population is among the most richly endowed European countries (Belgium 830, Denmark 823, France 931, Ireland 385, Netherlands 594, Average for Europe 940). Many structures, however, are old and have been poorly maintained. Many renovation will be needed in the next 20 years. 29. The number of Government health facilities is more than adequate but these structures are generaUly old, their technology obsolete and they lack modern management and quality control. At the periphery, there have been shortages of (i) essential drugs which may now be getting out of reach of some vulnerable groups because of costs; and (ii) diagnostic and clinical medical equipment. Difficult working conditions and low salaries lead to low morale among the health providers. As a result of these shortcomings, the PHC level has deteriorated and the population tends to bypass the primary care level to seek care in hospitals where free drugs and minimum standards of care remain available. The use of secondary or tertiary care institutions to provide primary health care and, even at times, social services increases unnecessarily the cost of health care delivery. C. Human Resources 30.  - 105 - Annex 3 Page 2 of 16 BULGARIA HEALTH SECTOR RESTRUCTURING PROJECT ORGANIZATION AND FINANCE OF THE HEALTH SYSTEM I. INTRODUCTION 1. The Bulgarian health system is characteristic of former socialist economies, with: (i) tax-based financing; (ii) public sector provision of services; (iii) universal access to comprehensive care; (iv) centralized planning and management; (v) extensive infrastructure and staffing; and (vi) few incentives for consumers or providers to increase efficiency, control costs and improve the quality of care. Recognizing the positive contribution of the public health system to the improvement in health status over the past forty years (particularly in combatting infectious diseases), it is nonetheless clear that inefficient allocation of resources is limiting the effectiveness of the system in preventing and reversing recent declines in health status. The country has embarked on a process of reform of the health system, aimed at maintaining broad access to care, while developing alternative inancing and reimbursement mechanisms, encouraging private sector health services, decentralizing the management of public services, streamlining the public network and introducing appropriate incentives for efficiency and quality of care. Reform to date has been slow and tentative, as the country struggles to achieve political consensus on the direction and pace of change. The Ministry of Health (MOH), responsible for development and implementation of health policy, has a formidable task ahead in linking strategic options to agreed objectives, and building a national consensus through public awareness and social marketing of proposed reforms. II. ORGANIZATION AND MANAGEME OF HEALTH SERVICES 2. The public sector health system is organized along the lines of district and municipal administration. The territory consists of 27 districts plus the capital city, encompassing more than 270 municipalities. It has been decided to group the 27 districts into nine larger regions, but no administrative structure is in place to operationalize this decision. The hierarchy of public health facilities consists of: (i) rural health posts, district health centers and urban polyclinics (freestanding and hospital-based) for ambulatory care; (ii) municipal hospitals (250-300 beds each) and district hospitals (1,000 beds each) for secondary care; and (iii) medical academies and a wide variety of specialized hospitals and institutes for tertiary care. The public sector health system also includes an extensive, but poorly performing, network of emergency medical services (EMS), and a network of 27
 -106 - Annex 3 Page 3 of 16 district and four regional Blood Transfusion Centers. The health information system is maintained by the National Center for Health Information (NCHI)and its 28 district offices, while public health, environmental concerns and food safety are addressed through national and district-based Sanitary and Epidemiologic Inspectorates. In addition, parallel health systems, including both ambulatory and inpatient facilities, are maintained by the Ministries of Transport, Interior, Labor and Defense. Although these systems are financed predominantly out of general revenues, they are restricted to specific social or occupational groups (e.g. transport workers). Private sector health services were authorized in 1991. Private services have grown rapidly in the pharmaceutical sector (para. 12) and in dentristry, with the establishment of approximately 1,700 private pharmacies and 6,000 private dentists. The development of other types of private medical services has been slowed by, among other factors, the lack of an appropriate financing mechanism. 3. Thus far, the most fundamental reform of the Bulgarian health system is contained in the 1991 Law on Municipal Autonomy which decentralized management and financing of district-based health facilities to the municipalities in which they are located. Even district hospitals and district-based, specialized institutes, both of which have catchment areas extending beyond a single municipality, fall under the jurisdiction of the municipality in which they are located. Many regulations hampering municipal management of facilities have been abolished in recent years. A municipal Commission on Health Care, consisting of health and social welfare personnel elected by the population, has responsibility for management of the municipal health system, and reports directly to the Municipal Council. District health authorities reporting directly to the MOH have a much diminished role relative to the past, with the Regional Center for Health Information serving as a conduit for information from the local level to the center. District-based health facilities have the legal status of municipal enterprises, limiting their managerial and financial autonomy. For example, while hospital directors have been granted some flexibility in staffing decisions, they must work within a fixed wage envelope determined by municipal authorities which cannot be reallocated to non-wage expenditures. National-level institutes and hospitals have the status of autonomous public enterprises--with some falling under the supervision of the MOH. 4. District and municipal health services are financed almost exclusively from a Municipal Budget (MB) which is distinct from the central, or Republican Budget (RB). While municipalities do have a limited tax base of their own, tax administration in Bulgaria is largely centralized, and the Municipal Budget is dominated by transfers from central budgetary revenues. A key issue following the decentralization of health system management has been the need to match resources at the municipal level with health care responsibilities, particularly when catchment areas extend beyond a single municipality. Measures to ensure this have thus far been inadequate (para. 19). Furthermore, economic contraction during the initial stage of the transition has imposed severe resource constraints on the health system-- particularly at the municipal level. In many municipalities, more than half of the municipal budget is allocated to health services. In a highly resource-constrained environment,
 - 107 - Annex 3 Page 4 of 16 municipal authorities are seeling ways to consolidate and restructure the public system and reallocate resources toward more cost-effective health interventions. However, structural reform at the municipal level has been hampered by: (i) lack of clear policy directives from the center; (ii) unclear legislative authority to take decisions on restructuring and reallocation; and (iii) lack of experience in using financial and service utilization data to make managerial decisions. 5. Increasing the efficiency of resource use in the public health system will require greater managerial autonomy for health facilities and the restructuring of financial incentives through the development of new cost reimbursement mechanisms. The MOH intends to promote these objectives through use of a contracting system between health facilities and municipalities (in an initial stage) and among health facilities, the proposed health financing administration and municipalities or client groups (in a later stage). Such a system would require, inter alia, change in the legal status of health facilities and development of cost parameters on which to base reimbursement. The NCHI has spearheaded an effort to develop simple cost accounting in municipal and district hospitals and determine the cost basis for health care reimbursement (para. 20). Pilot activities to test contractual arrangements and develop reimbursement mechanisms are proposed, and should be pursued in tandem with efforts to revise the legal and regulatory framework for ownership, management and financing of public and private health services. Public Sector Health Infrastructure 6. Hospital Care. The public sector health system in Bulgaria is plagued with: (i) excess capacity; (ii) poor differentiation of services for ambulatory, emergency and inpatient care; and, in recent years; (iii) declining utilization rates. With 12.8 hospital beds per 1,000 population (10.3 acute care beds and 2.5 sanitoria/rehabilitation beds), inpatient capacity is high by European standards--and all the more so given Bulgaria's income level (Tables 1 and 2). The situation has scarcely improved during the transition. Inpatient capacity in sanatoria and other rehabilitation centers fell by 15 percent in the 1990-92 period, but capacity in acute care hospitals fell by less than one percent. Bulgarian hospitals tend to have more separate wards for sub-specialties than comparable hospitals in Western Europe, and occupancy rates are frequently low. Although capacity is excessive, facilities tend to be old and poorly maintained, with obsolete technology and--as the fiscal crisis deepens-- shortages of spare parts, medical supplies and drugs. This is especially true at the municipal level and in rural areas, where budget constraints have been tightest. The resulting decline in the quality of care is undoubtedly one factor accounting for the fall in average occupancy rate, from 87 percent in 1985 to 73 percent in 1992. Occupancy rates have dropped furthest for district and municipal hospitals (to 73 and 69 percent, respectively, in 1992), and are extremely low for rural hospitals (22 percent). This is so, despite a long average length of stay (13.8 days) in hospitals, which boosts occupancy figures but is indicative of inefficiencies in inpatient care.
 - 108 - Annx 3 Page 5 of 16 7. Outpatient Care. Although hospitalization rates have declined in recent years, the ratio of hospitalizations to cases of illness remains relatively high, most probably reflecting the failure of outpatient services to effectively treat patients. Indeed, utilization of outpatient facilities has fallen far more dramatically than hospital use. Outpatient visits per capita rose from 5.0 in 1970 to 7.3 in 1985, before declining steadily to only 5.3 in 1992. Large disparities exist between use of outpatient services in urban areas (6.9 visits per capita) and rural areas (2.9 visits per capita). The primary care network is extensive, with one ambulatory care center per 2,300 population in 1992. However, nearly 60 percent of these are rural health posts with limited access to essential drugs and supplies. In fact, primary care services in Bulgaria tend to be poorly differentiated from emergency medical services, and the country lacks effective "front line" family medicine, particularly in rural areas. As a result, hospitals provide a disproportionate share of primary health services--one reason hospitals account for 55 percent of all outpatient visits (urban polyclinics provide another 30 percent). In coming years, high priority must be accorded to the strengthening of "front line" preventive and curative primary care services in both the public and private sector, in order to reverse deteriorating health status and avoid using hospitals as costly providers of routine primary care. 8. Emergency Care. Strengthening the front line will depend on disentangling routine primary health services from emergency care, and making emergency medical services (EMS) a fast and reliable link between primary and secondary facilities. Among the weaknesses of the existing EMS are: a. unclear mandate which covers emergency care, routine primary health care, home visits and miscellaneous transport needs; b. decentralized administration; c. poor integration between mobile services and hospital emergency wards; d. lack of polyvalent emergency rooms; e. oversized, obsolete and unreliable ambulance fleet; and, f. inappropriate staffing patterns, with overspecialized physicians and undertrained paramedical staff. To rectify this situation, the MOH intends to strengthen EMS through: (i) recentralization of EMS administration; (ii) development of an integrated telecommunications system; (iii) downsizing and upgrading of the ambulance fleet; (iv) redeployment and retraining of staff; (v) reorganization and reequipment of emergency rooms; and (vi) revising emergency medicine curricula.

The total number of personnel (not including MOH personnel) fell by eight percent in the 1990-92 period, to around 117,000. All categories of staff declined, with the number of physicians falling least (5 percent) and the number of pharnacists and pharmacy assistants falling most (40 and 23 percent, respectively). These figures are in keeping with the establishment of approximately 1,700 private pharmacies in Bulgaria by end-1993. It is also believed that most of the nearly 1,500 physicians to leave public service are in private practice in Bulgaria or abroad. 10. With 3.1 physicians per 1,000 population and 2.4 nursing persons (nurses, midwives, feldchers) per physician, medical staffing levels are in the upper range for European countries, and more than adequate to address the needs of the population (Table 2). However, medical staff tend to be poorly and/or inappropriately trained to meet the basic health care needs of the population. Eighty percent of physicians are specialists (including 14 percent pediatricians and 6 percent gynecologists), with most of the remaining generalists studying towards their specialization. Medical education lacks a family medicine curriculum and produces no general practitioners--although more than 40 percent of physicians work at the primary care level. Likewise, nurses are not trained as nurse practitioners. Pre-service and in-service training in family medicine, coupled with better supply of essential drugs to peripheral areas, will be the key to improved quality of primary health care in coming years. 11. Average wages for public sector health personnel have traditionally trailed behind average wages in the formal economy, but rose by approximately 20 percent in real terms between 1989 and 1992. Wage and employment policy is determined through negotiation between the MOH and the trade unions representing health personnel. AR staff reduction and redeployment must be negotiated with the trade unions, which are entitled to participate in all management decisions of health facilities. The most recent Sector Agreement (April 1993) establishes wage rates for five categories of health facilities based on coefficients applied to an adjusted minimum salary. The base pay scale is quite flat, with a maximum salary of only 2.7 times the minimum. However, bonuses for advanced degrees, specializations, seniority and specific fields (e.g. surgery, anaesthesiology, emergency care) add as much as 70 percent or more to base salaries. Within the framework of the Sector Agreement, the MOH establishes an average gross wage for all municipally-funded facilites which then determines the budgetary envelope for the MB wagebill. In addition, municipalities have the right to increase the average gross wage for health (and education) personnel by as much as 20 percent as an added incentive, using municipal resources or savings generated within municipal transfers. For 1994, the average gross wage in force for municipally-funded facilities is 3,344 BGL/month. For tertiary facilities funded by the Republican Budget, the average gross wage established ranges from 4,300-4,800 BGL/month depending on the facility. Including various bonuses, specialized physicians in tertiary care

During the socialist era, the State had a monopoly on pharmaceutical production, import-export and distribution in Bulgaria. In 1991, the market was liberalized, including: (i) authorization of private sector importers, wholesalers and retailers; (ii) dissolution of public sector production facilities into 20 independent, state-owned factories; (iii) dissolution of public sector distribution facilties into 28 state-owned district wholesalers; and (iv) authorization for health facilities to purchase drugs on the open market. As a result of these measures, the private sector has grown quickly--a largely positive development--albeit in a virtually unregulated manner. Procurement by the public sector has become highly fragmented, resulting in inefficiencies due to small volume purchases, poor market information and general inexperience at the facility level. The number of registered substances and dosage forms has increased threefold (nearly 1,000 substances and 3,600 dosage forms by end-1993) due to a surge in imports, while domestic drug industries have sought bigger profits and foreign exchange earnings by exporting 80 percent of their production. 13. Pricing policy for pharmaceuticals is evolving. Prices on domestic production are loosely controlled in the domestic market (cost plus 20 percent margin). Price controls in the domestic market add to incentives to export at uncontrolled prices. Import prices are not controlled, but internal distribution margins for imported drugs were regulated (3 percent for import handling, 25 percent for wholesale/retail distribution) starting in 1993. Use of ad valorem margins, however, adds to incentives to market more expensive drugs and dosage forms. Reimbursement policy has also fueled cost escalation. The state reimburses 100 percent of drug costs in inpatient facilites and 25-100 percent for drugs bought in public and private pharmacies, depending on the substance. In addition, the state reimburses 100 percent of drug costs for households below the poverty line, and 50 percent of drug costs for households between 100 and 130 percent of the poverty line. No cap is placed on state reimbursement for specific drugs, encouraging the use of more expensive brands and dosage forms. Reimbursement mechanisms have also not kept pace with development of the private market: private pharmacies submit invoices for reimbursement through hospital pharmacies-- an inappropriate administrative burden for public hospitals. 14. The National Drug Institute (NDI), charged with implementation of drug policy, regulation of the market and drug registration, quality control and inspection, suggests that existing reimbursement policy is both overly complex and fiscally unsustainable. The state covered nearly 75 percent of the cost of the BGL 3.8 billion spent on drugs in 1992, amounting to about 17 percent of public health expenditures. This is a relatively high share by international standards, and fiscal contraction in 1993 and 1994 have strained the capacity of the state to maintain drug expenditures, resulting in payment delays

A new Drug Law establishing the basic regulatory framework for the pharmaceutical market has been submitted to Parliament, and awaits action.
