FINANCING OF HEALTH SERVICES 15. Health services in Bulgaria are financed almost entirely from general tax revenues allocated via the budget, with 2-3 percent of revenues deriving from out-of-pocket user fees (mostly for pharmaceuticals). Budget allocations are based largely on historic levels which tend to reflect fixed and quasi-fixed inputs: number of facilities, beds and staff. Ailocations do not reflect anticipated service volume, nor have they been adjusted to take into account shifting pattems of service utilization in recent years. At the municipal level, municipal transfers have historically been the subject of political negotiation, and have not necessarily reflected the changing needs of the health system, and shifting pattems of facility use. Revenue and Reimbursement Mechanisms 16. Tax-based health systems offer the advantages of facilitating universal access to care and minimizing financial risk for health care consumers. However, the existing budgeting system for public health facilities in Bulgaria suffers from the following weaknesses: (i) few incentives for cost consciousness among consumers, who pay no out-of- pocket costs for care; (ii) no transfer of financial risk (or reward) to providers in order to create incentives to improve efficiency, consolidate redundant services and improve quality to attract clientele; and (iii) no reimbursement mechanism for private services which would permit private sector development. Fiscal contraction in recent years has also sparked a search for new sources of revenue to finance health services. Initially, adoption of contributory national health insurance legislation tended to be viewed as a panacea for these problems. Various interest groups compromised on draft legislation which was submitted to Parliament in 1993. However, the initial draft raises two fundamental questions: (i) the feasibility of a contribution-based insurance system in the present Bulgarian context; and (ii) the administrative practicality of a decentralized institutional framework. 17. The draft Health Insurance Law establishes a system which is ostensibly financed predominantly from payroll contributions. However, payroll contributions in Bulgaria already account for nearly 60 percent of gross wage payments--a very high rate which significantly distorts the cost of labor in the economy. Increasing this rate to 68-72
 -112 - Annex 3 Page 9 of 16 percent--a conservative estimate of the cost of health services--would be unacceptable in any country, but all the more so in a country facing the social pressure of mounting unemployment associated with the economic transition. Additional payroll taxation does not represent a source of significant financing for the health system. Initially, the Health Insurance Law proposed the establishment of 28 independent, non-profit insurance companies with territorial monopolies for compulsory insurance. However, it was ultimately recognized that their risk pools would be too small for optimal risk-sharing. Revised legislation has subsequently proposed the establishment of one national insurance company, with 28 branches. However, the issue of excessive payroll taxation has not been adequately addressed. 18. The proposed insurance legislation provides a framework for health financing, without defining specific reimbursement mechanisms. Some type of contracting between providers and insurers is assumed, and yet, it is the development of new reimbursement mechanisms which will determine the incentives for increased efficiency, improved quality of care and development of private health services. Without first defining these reimbursement mechanisms, it is difficult to assess the impact of introducing health insurance on the demand and supply of services, and on public spending for health. Indeed, legitimate concerns about uncontrolled cost escalation--particularly at a time of severe fiscal austerity--have reduced the political urgency of adopting health insurance legislation. In the meantime, the Ministries of Health and Finance, as well as the National Center for Health Information (NCHI) and the National Insurance Research and Development Center (NIRDC) have begun to define and test new reimbursement mechanisms for health services. 19. In the absence of more fundamental financial reform, the Ministries of Health and Finance have sought to improve the existing system of municipal budgeting by developing "objective criteria" to determine municipal transfers. However, political opposition to changing historic transfer levels has been strong, and the logic guiding the chosen methodology is unclear. Furthermore, while the methodology determines the global envelope of transfers to each municipality, it does nothing to change the incentives facing health facilities and other municipal services--a change that can only occur through development of new reimbursement mechanisms. According to the methodology, municipal transfers are determined by: (i) historic levels adjusted for inflation; (ii) capital investments (proposed by the municipality); (iii) per capita income in the municipality; and (iv) a weighted set of 17 "objective criteria". The set of criteria is heavily weighted (63 percent) toward three factors: population, number of settlements and number of secondary school students. Ratios of patients per bed in municipal and district hospitals account for 13 percent of the weighting. Overall, the rationale behind the numerous criteria and their weighting is unclear. However, the objective criteria applied to only 11 percent of the aggregate municipal transfer in 1994, resulting in little reallocation of resources relative to the past. 20. Efforts to rationalize municipal transfers should be pursued, with an improved methodology. In general, municipal budgets should be based directly on unit costs for
 -113 - Annex 3 Page 10 of 16 municipal services provided (e.g. cost of secondary education per pupil, per household cost of trash collection, etc.). Similarly, for municipal health services, budgets should reflect activity levels--reimbursing for services rendered--with phasing out of underutilized and/or redundant facilities and services. In fact, the public health system has the necessary cost and utilization data to develop a more flexible budgeting system based on services rendered and identify necessary streamlining of the system. For the past few years, the NCHI has introduced simple cost accounting (by ward and by expenditure category) in municipal and district hospitals and polyclinics to complement patient and utilization data traditionally collected for the health information system. While the financial accounting system is in an early phase--with associated problems of data reliability and data processing capabilities-it does provide a sufficient basis for calculating average costs, developing simple, cost-based reimbursement mechanisms and making efficiency comparisons. The NCHI intends to carry out pilot activities to improve district resource allocation, by using existing financial and service utilization data to: (i) identify the potential for streamlining public health services; and (ii) develop reimbursement mechanisms which create financial incentives for efficient resource allocation. 21. Building on the work of the NCHI, the NIRDC has outlined a medium-term strategy to introduce a case-mix, diagnosis-related approach to hospital reimbursement, based on grouping of patients according to ICD-9 categories. Initially, patients would be grouped by ward only, with reimbursement based on average unit costs per ward. Gradually, diagnostic groups would be separated from the ward groupings, with reimbursement based on average cost of treatment. Successful implementation of such a system will require refinement of the cost accounting system, strengthening of financial analysis and development of more complex administrative mechanisms. Financial and technical support from the international community is being sought for medium term development of this reimbursement mechanism. At the same time, more attention should be focused on the relatively easier task of developing a reimbursement mechanism for outpatient family practice, in order to strengthen primary care and support the emergence of private sector general practitioners. Trends in Health EWenditures 22. As in other former socialist countries, the initial phase of the transition has entailed economic and fiscal contraction, with gross domestic product falling by 25 percent and government spending by 40 percent in real terms between 1989 and 1993. Despite this unprecedented contraction, the Government succeeded in maintaining--and even moderately increasing (by seven percent)--aggregrate real spending for health during this period (Table 4). This is in marked contrast to most other former socialist economies, where economic contraction has resulted, to varying degrees, in compression of real health expenditures. As a result, public spending for health rose as a share of GDP from 3.4 percent in 1989 to 5.4 percent in 1992--a level which is not high by Western European standards, but is in the upper range for countries at Bulgaria's income level. Given the
 - 114 - Annex 3 Page 11 of 16 magnitude of the general fiscal contraction, health expenditures more than doubled as a share of government spending, from 5.8 percent in 1989 to 11.9 percent in 1992. However, Bulgaria could not sustain this level of health expenditures as the transition deepened. Fiscal pressures have made spending cuts inevitable, with public spending on health falling as a share of GDP to 5.1 percent in 1993 and 4.7% of GDP in 1994. 23. All growth in real spending for health in the 1989-93 period was for current expenditures. An initial surge in the wagebill was tempered in later years, while spending for drugs, operating costs and other goods and services increased moderately, peaking in 1992. In contrast, capital spending, including rehabilitation and new investment, declined by around 20 percent in real terms. Virtually all expenditure categories experienced cutbacks in 1993 and 1994. Reductions were ad hoc in nature, with little restructuring of the public health system. The challenge for Government in the next few years will be to selectively maintain public spending in those areas which have the greatest impact on the health status of the population, while eliminating inefficient and ineffective uses of public resources. 24. Of greatest concern for the health status of the population is the fact that all growth in health spending in recent years has accrued exclusively to the Republican Budget, which supports specialized tertiary care and health administration. Spending for the Republican Budget increased by 60 percent in real terms between 1989 and 1992, while spending for the Municipal Budget--which supports more cost-effective primary and secondary care--virtually stagnated.Y As a result, municipal spending fell as a share of total health expenditures from 81 percent in 1989 to 72 percent in 1992. This at a time when resources need to be shifted into basic health services, which have the greatest impact on health status and the greatest potential to protect vulnerable groups from disease and premature death during the transition. Failure to restructure and streamline the public sector health infrastructure at all levels has hindered the reallocation of resources toward more cost- effective interventions. The trend in spending was reversed in 1993, with real expenditures under the Republican Budget falling by eight percent, and municipal spending increasing by seven percent. However, this reversal does not entirely compensate for past trends, leaving relative spending for the Municipal Budget well below pre-transition levels. 25. Given the severity of revenue shortfalls, it is remarkable that Government maintained--and even modestly increased--real spending in health throughout the 1989-93 period. Investment spending alone suffered significant real declines--a not wholly undesirable outcome, given the nature of the investments which have been selected. The public investment program during the transition has been a hodge-podge of inappropriate projects, not subject to objective economic and social evaluation criteria. The 1993 "priority" investment program consisted almost entirely of construction and completion of specialized I' This is true after adjusting for the transfer of certain health services (e.g. Regional Centers for Health Information, Regional Sanitary Inspectorates) to the Republican budget, beginning in 1992.
 - 115 - Annex 3 Page 12 of 16 tertiary care hospitals and secondary hospitals for parallel health systems with restricted access (e.g. transport workers only). If completed, the 1993 program would have added at least 1,500-2,000 hospital beds to existing, underutilized inpatient capacity. New investment needs to be linked to rationalization of existing infrastructure. As it now stands,the program is an amalgam of special interest projects proposed by municipalities and the medical community, with the Ministries of Health and Finance playing no role in the selection of investments which are most cost-effective (i.e. produce the greatest improvement in health status for the least cost). This is unfortunate, for the investment needs of the sector are great, in order to strengthen front line primary care, rehabilitate emergency and blood supply services and upgrade outmoded hospital equipment. Despite a justifiable tendency toward decentralization in the management of the public health sector, it will be important in coming years to recognize the legitimate role of the central government (in this case, the Ministries of Health and Finance) in establishing public investment policy and applying objective criteria for arbitrage among competing investment proposals.

 - 121 - Annex 4 Page 1 of 7 BULGARIA HEALTH SECTOR RESTRUCTURING PROJECT MINISTRY OF HEALTH STATEMENT OF POLICY DIRECTIONS FOR HEALTH SECTOR REFORM Policy Objectives 1. The health policy of Ministry of Health (MoH) will be directed towards the achievement of the following priority objectives: a. Protect and improve the health status of the population with regard to specific risk groups; b. Restructure the health care system based on primary health care aimed at improving the health status and encourage a healthy lifestyle as well as improve the health system performance; c. Further develop the structural reform in the health sector in conformity with the elaborated National Health Strategy; d. Guarantee equal access, equity and justice in the health care for all citizens. 2. Health care policy shall preserve its social character and it is aimed at improving peoples' health , preventing diseases, improving the efficiency of health care by improving the quality of services and achieving a just allocation of resources. During the process of implementing it is essential to maintain the political and social trust of the people in the health care reform. 3. In this respect the achievement of a balance between rapid and tangible results in certain essential health care fields will be essential.
 - 122 - Annex 4 Page 2 of 7 Strategyfor reform 4. To achieve the objectives of health policy MoH has finalized a National Health Strategy based on in-depth analysis of the exsting situation, problems and priority areas for action in the health sector. A further step in this respect will be the development of a National Action Plan for the implementation of the strategy. The MoH has focused its activities based on the following priority areas: * reduction of cardio-vascular diseases; * improving the prevention and treatment of neoplasms; * reduction of infant mortality; . improving the care for the aged population, the handicapped and the unemployed * protecting the health of women in reproductive age In order to achieve progress in the a.m. priority areas coordination action will be taken in the prevention of diseases, health promotion, PHC, environmental health, women's health, perinatal care, blood transfusion and other fields. 5. The MoH is undertaking a legislative initiative to provide legal grounds and regulations of the health sector reform activities. This initiative includes the elaboration of new laws, amendments to the existing legislation and development of new regulatory acts related to: * management of health system * hospital management * health care financing * the status of non-governmental medical associations * private practice * health promotion and disease prevention * drug policy 6. The process of change in the health system is aimed at promoting more efficient and effective utilization of the resources allocated to meet health demands. In this sense the change should be perceived as an adaptation and restructuring of the existing health care system, taking into account new quantitative or qualitative requirements. It is essential that this process covers the demand for new financial, technical or technological resources.
 - 123- Annex 4 Page 3 of 7 Restructuring of the health system The effectiveness and efficiency of health care will be improved through the restructuring and upgrading of the health system in order to adequately adapt the country's health care institutions' infrastructure in accordance with the modified health and demographic status of the population, the decentralization process and the introduction of a health insurance system. With respect to the system as a whole, the following measures have been or will be taken: a. Creation of Regional health authorities. Such regional bodies have been created with the decree No. 145 of COM published in State Gazette of 17.07.95 named as Regional Health Centers. b. A uniform hospital management model was established aimed at increased responsibility and accountability for performing the management functions in an environment of greater autonomy. c. Pilot projects started in 2 regions of the country (Smolyan and Gabrovo) with the aim of introducing and testing basic elements of a health insurance system. d. Re-establishment of the National Public Health Center and the National Center for Health Promotion is foreseen in the near future. 7. In addition, the MoH will undertake other activities outlined in the National Health Strategy (NHS) (a copy of which is supplied to the WB administration). The sequence in order and time of those activities will be given in the National Action Plan (NAP). 8. Provision of high-priority, basic health services will be ensured through restructuring and upgrading of the key networks outlined below. Prim=r Health care 9. On May 31st 1994, the MoH issued ordinance no. 10, distinguishing primary health care services from emergency medical services and defining their respective roles in providing 24-hour care. Starting this year the MoH
 - 124 - Amex4 Page 4 of 7 will contract with the municipalities to upgrade basic equipment and facilities for primary care and provide training in general practice medicine and community health, contingent on municipal commitment to: a. rationalize PHC coverage through adjustments in infrastructure and staffing, with particular regard for underserved areas; b. implement a standard PHC package including 24-hour curative care, a range of freventive services related to maternal and child health and other preventive and promotive activities according to national disease priorities; These commitments will be adapted to the needs of each municipality. Commitment contracts will be signed with approximately 75 municipalities to carry out these activities in the next 5 years. Emergency Medical Services 10. The COM issued a decree on 17.02.1994 to create a centralized emergency medical service (EMS) under national authority in an initial 7 districts (ordinance no. 37). A second decree was approved by COM on 29.09.1994 to extend this to an additional 7 districts, and Government intends to progressively establish a centralized EMS administration nation- wide. The MoH also issued ordinance no. 7 on 25.05.1994 to define the structure and functions of EMS centers and establish the legal framework for their operation. The MoH has begun signing separation protocols with municipalities to transfer local EMS assets (vehicles, staff, equipment) to central authorities. This is a prerequisite to an ongoing program for restructuring and upgrading of EMS which will: a. eliminate non-emergency, routine primary care and home-visits from EMS; b. set up a modem EMS telecommunications network; c. establish and equip polyvalent emergency rooms; d. downsize and modernize the ambulance fleet, and adjust staff accordingly; e. improve integration of mobile services and hospital emergency rooms;
 -125- Annex 4 Page 5 of 7 Blood Transfusion 11. As a first step in a programme to improve the supply and safety of blood and blood products, Parliament passed the law on Blood Collection and Transfusion on 30.03.94, establishing standards for the collection, processing and transfusion of blood. At the same time, the MoH improved the safety of the blood supply and adopted more efficient technology for the blood collection by replacing glass bottles with plastic bags throughout the system. MoH is now prepariig a decree to establish a centralized blood transfusion network and transfer associated assets from the municipalities to the central authorities. This is a part of a planned strategy to restructure and rehabilitate the blood transfusion network which will: a. concentrate most blood processing and quality control activities in 5 Regional Transfusion Centers, downsizing the network by lirniting smaller centers to blood collection functions only (phasing out other functions and adjusting staff accordingly); b. upgrade the equipment and technology for blood collection and processing in line with Council of Europe standards; c. re-organize the National Donor Recruitment program with non- governmental involvement, and improve public relations techniques. Health Fian 12. Reform of health financing will seek to mobilize and increase the efficiency of the existing health resources by adapting the health sector to the new conditions of a market economy and budgetary constraints. To begin this process, amendments to the existing Public Health Law are prepared. 13. A new draft Law on Health Insurance establishing the broad outlines for a contributory national health insurance system will be finalized soon and presented to Parliament. In order to better define the modalities for the implementation of such a system the following activities are underway: a. MoH has approved a proposal for various methods of contracting the amount and quality of medical services and their payment between the consumers and providers of health care;
 Annex 4 -126- Page 6 of 7 b. a system of cost accounting by department and type of expenditure has been introduced on a pilot basis in municipal level in-patient and out-patient facilities; c. simple efficiency comparisons are being made on the basis of costs data, and a link has been established between budgetary allocations and service volume. 14. In the next few years the capacity of MoH to analyze policy options related to health finance and management will be strengthened while reform will focus on: a. updating the existing health statistics information system and facilities-based management information systems in accordance with modern standards and streamlining the national health information administration; b. short-term development of a flexible budgeting method to be adopted by the Ministry of Finance for municipal and national level health facilities which will explicitly link public resource allocation to the volume of services rendered; - c. longer-term development of case-mix, diagnosis-related method of reimbursement for health services which will link resource allocation to service volume as well as provide maximum incentives for efficiency and cost-containment; d. defining the resource base (pay-roll contributions, budgetary revenues, user fees etc.) expenditure (minimum package of insured services) and contracting methods of a national health insurance system; e. building the capacity and the authority of the MoH to evaluate and select public investment proposals (at the central and municipal levels) according to cost-effectiveness criteria; f. introduction of new postgraduate training system for experts having higher or special medical education, which would include training in health administration, management and marketing.
 -127- Annex 4 Page 7 of 7 Concluding Remarks 15. The new health care strategy requires shared responsibilities for the development of the health sector and the application of practical mechanisms of real partnership between the state institutions, the public organizations and the health experts. Implementation of the strategy must be spearheaded by every department of the MoH, which must internalize the strategic aims and objectives, and take responsibility for acting upon them. 16. It is oriented toward the maximum utilization of the experience of the developed countries, international institutions and organizations in the field of health care and the implementation of the financial resources and know- how provided by the latter. 17. The achievement of the above defined aims and the implementation of a health insurance system should guarantee high quality and accessible health services for the Bulgarian population with the possibility of free choice of physicians and medical institutions, and professional fulfillment and an honored position in society for the medical community. doc.abstracts: The objective of the Health Sector Restructuring Project is to prevent further deterioration in the health status of the population, while at the same time improving the efficiency of the health care delivery system. The project comprises four main components: (i) policy analysis and management which will primarily assist the Ministry of Health (MOH) in building up a capacity for policy analysis and evaluation and will finance a limited number of key studies such as a burden of disease analysis and cost-effectiveness studies; (ii) primary health care which will improve the quality and scope of primary health care in selected municipalities; (iii) emergency medical services which will support ongoing efforts by MOH to restructure emergency medical services and improve the effectiveness and efficiency of service delivery; and (iv) blood transfusion which will assist current efforts to improve the supply and quality of blood and blood products by restructuring and rehabilitating the network of blood transfusion centers by introducing safer and more up to date technology and by actively promoting the recruitment of new donors.
